div.p: Most Reverend Father in Christ, although I know that our Erastus is already writing to you extensively, I thought it would be more pleasing to you if I added some letters, rather than merely conveying greetings to you through this Zacharias, a pious young man.

Therefore, in brief, know this, honorable father, that we need your prayers at this time, and indeed very earnestly; for we are called into a conflict by the imprudence of certain men, which I wish God would turn to good by His providence! From Erastus's letters, you have undoubtedly understood the matter more fully.

I wish they were not the beginnings of great evils! I am sending you the remaining part of the sermons. Illyricus has written against me by name; whether you judge it necessary to respond to him, I wish to understand from you.

If a response is necessary, I will do so modestly and seriously, as much as the Lord will grant, and I will do so with the intention of using his name as a mask and an opportunity to defend the truth.
For since he is hated by many throughout Germany, most will want to read what is written against him in contempt of him.
I would not want to be attached to his writing, but to handle the whole cause in my own method and refute it in its proper place. I ask you to advise me briefly on what you suggest.
May the Lord Jesus preserve you for the church.
Given at Heidelberg, April 5, 1564. Yours sincerely, Kaspar Olevianus.
To the Reverend Father in Christ, Lord Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful minister of the church in Zürich, my honorable lord. In Zürich.
